bestBHT.bht: The blind man called out to Jesus, saying Rabboni or My Master, showing respect and acknowledging Jesus as his Lord. The man expressed his desire to receive his sight, using the word αναβλεψω which means to recover sight or see again. He believed that Jesus had the power to grant this request in the best way. The blind man's cry for mercy and his recognition of Jesus as the great master and Lord of the world were evident in his plea to regain his sight.

Henry Alford: 51.] Rabboni, i.e. Master, or My Master, see John xx. 16. It was said to be a more respectful form than Rabbi merely.
Philip Schaff: Master (or my Master). The word is ‘Rabboni’ (as in John 20:10), the most respectful of the three titles, Rab, Rabbi, Rabboni. Comp. Matthew 23:7.
That I may receive my sight, or, ‘see again.’ Not how or why, but the desire, which he believes the Lord can grant in the best way.
Archibald T. Robertson: Rabboni (Ραββουνε). The Aramaic word translated Lord (Kurie) in Matthew 20:33 and Luke 18:41.
That I may receive my sight (ινα αναβλεψω). To recover sight (ανα-), see again.
John Gill: What means this vehement cry? what is it thou designest by mercy?"
Thou, great master in Israel, and Lord of the whole world, my request to thee..."
That I might receive my sight.

bhtAttempts.bht: The blind man called out to Jesus, saying Rabboni or My Master, showing respect and acknowledging Jesus as his Lord. The man expressed his desire to receive his sight, using the word αναβλεψω which means to recover sight or see again. He believed that Jesus had the power to grant this request in the best way. The blind man's cry for mercy and his recognition of Jesus as the great master and Lord of the world were evident in his plea to regain his sight.

The blind man respectfully called Jesus Rabboni, acknowledging Him as his Master. He fervently desired to receive his sight and believed that Jesus had the power to restore his vision. By using the word αναβλεψω to express his desire to see again, the man demonstrated his faith in Jesus' ability to perform this miracle. His plea for mercy and recognition of Jesus as the great master and Lord of the world were evident in his request for the restoration of his sight.

The blind man respectfully cried out to Jesus, saying Rabboni or My Master, acknowledging Him as his Lord. His fervent desire was to receive his sight and he believed that Jesus had the power to restore his vision. By using the word αναβλεψω to express his longing to see again, the blind man demonstrated his unwavering faith in Jesus' ability to perform this miracle. His plea for mercy and recognition of Jesus as the great master and Lord of the world were evident in his heartfelt request for the restoration of his sight.

The blind man respectfully called out to Jesus, addressing Him as Rabboni, a more respectful form of Rabbi. He urgently desired to receive his sight, expressing his belief that Jesus had the power to restore his vision. Using the word αναβλεψω, meaning to recover sight or see again, emphasized his hope in Jesus' ability to perform this miracle. Through his plea for mercy and acknowledgment of Jesus as the great master and Lord, the blind man sought the restoration of his sight with humility and faith.

The blind man, showing reverence, called out to Jesus as Rabboni, his Master. He earnestly sought to receive his sight, believing that Jesus had the power to restore his vision. With the word αναβλεψω, meaning to recover sight or see again, he expressed his hope in Jesus' ability to perform this miracle. Through his plea for mercy, the blind man acknowledged Jesus as the great master and Lord of the world, entrusting his request for restored sight to Him.
